text: my name is Andrew Morton I wrote Diana
her true story 25 years ago I've brought
it up to date and I'd like you to read
this book and realize what a fun person
Dinah was well I was writing a biography
of Dinah and my main contact was a chap
called James Colt Hearst at some point
he was letting to die in a secret and
the secret was that her life was
miserable lonely unhappy and she
strongly suspected that her husband was
living with another man's wife and I
didn't realize this I believe in the
fairy tale and at some point after
testing me with a few stories and
requests she said would Andrea like an
interview well here was the world's most
famous woman about to give me some
information about her life I thought
she'd be talking telling telling me
about her humanitarian work her charity
work not so it was it was the most
detailed intimate story that anybody
could have imagined
we spoke to her on tape six times James
would cycle up to Kensington Palace on
take his tape recorder with him
ostensibly he was there to see her as a
friend and she was sitting her
sitting-room put on the microphone and
chat away as she answered my questions
did you have any clue when you were
writing the book when you were listening
to those tapes about how explosive it
was going to be virtually from the first
moment I heard the first tape and I
listened to the tape in a workingman's
caffeine in Ruislip in North London put
on a pair of headphones heard Dinah
talking about her lonely life a
desperation of sense of unhappiness how
she wanted out of the royal family how
she and Prince Charles had a the
relationship abated he collapsed it was
it was like being admitted into a
parallel universe
I was absolutely stunned so much so that
when I spoke to my publisher about it he
said well is it a con man because he
pointed to all the books in his in his
office and said all these diner books
look if she's so unhappy how come she's
always smiling why do you think she
retains such irrelevance today 800
million people watched her marriage to
Prince Charles's and Paul's Cathedral
800 million people and the unchanged
invested part of themselves in in in
watching how this couple progressed in
life and they saw with Diana this
innocent young girl brought into this
family and they watched her progress and
it was like a living soap opera
